item.title: Shell into Kubernetes Pod
item.description: Syntax: 1kubectl exec --stdin --tty <pod_name> -- /bin/bash Example, with the following pods 1me@example:~$ kubectl get pod 2NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE 3cert-manager-cainjector-68c88cc858-c2rhx 1/1 Running 0 109m 4cert-manager-d76d644df-pgqn9 1/1 Running 0 109m 5cert-manager-webhook-6dd68c6fbc-rzcln 1/1 Running 0 109m 6my-first-vanilla-drupal-6f6dd66b94-xldj7 1/1 Running 0 108m 7my-first-vanilla-drupal-mariadb-0 1/1 Running 0 108m 8traffic-cop-nginx-ingress-controller-5d685cfd59-pjfdg 1/1 Running 0 144m 9traffic-cop-nginx-ingress-default-backend-55f6bcb48-brg6b 1/1 Running 0 144m Run this to go to the drupal pod my-first-vanilla-drupal-6f6dd66b94-xldj7 1kubectl exec --stdin --tty my-first-vanilla-drupal-6f6dd66b94-xldj7 -- /bin/bash It's just like any docker container or linux machine when you're in:

item.title: Adding Helm Repo
item.description: A Helm Repo that's in https://github.com/codecentric/helm-charts has a corresponding repo URL. Add it as follows: 1user@example:~$ helm repo add codecentric https://codecentric.github.io/helm-charts 2"codecentric" has been added to your repositories

item.title: Change Default Cluster in Kubernetes
item.description: If you have more than one cluster as illustrated in https://ismael.casimpan.com/quicktasks-k8s/list-nodes-in-kubernetes/, you can change it using command: 1kubectl config use-context <cluster_name_here> Use this command to verify the change: 1kubectl config get-contexts

item.title: Checking PersistentVolumeClaims
item.description: 1user@example:~$ kubectl get pvc --all-namespaces 2NAMESPACE NAME STATUS VOLUME CAPACITY ACCESS MODES STORAGECLASS AGE 3testing-icasimpan-com vol-mysql-mysql-0 Bound pvc-bd199911-e0e5-4327-885d-4902a599ebe2 10Gi RWO do-block-storage 12m

item.title: Get Cluster List in Kubernetes
item.description: If you have a lot of kubernetes cluster, you will see the following: 1user@example:~$ kubectl config get-contexts 2CURRENT NAME CLUSTER AUTHINFO NAMESPACE 3* do-nyc1-kubernetes-tutorial do-nyc1-kubernetes-tutorial do-nyc1-kubernetes-tutorial-admin 4do-nyc3-infra do-nyc3-infra do-nyc3-infra-admin 5do-nyc2-devinfra do-nyc2-devinfra do-nyc2-devinfra-admin The one with asterisk (do-nyc1-kubernetes-tutorial) is your current cluster. So "kubectl" commands without specified cluster will default to it.

item.title: Installing Software using Helm
item.description: Say you want install jenkins and corresponding repo already added. 1user@example:~$ helm install jenkins codecentric/jenkins 2NAME: jenkins 3LAST DEPLOYED: Sun Jun 28 09:59:52 2020 4NAMESPACE: default 5STATUS: deployed 6REVISION: 1 7TEST SUITE: None 8NOTES: 9************************************************************************ 10* * 11* Jenkins Helm Chart by codecentric AG * 12* * 13************************************************************************ 1415In case the chart was installed with the default configuration and you did not 16configure an admin user, Jenkins creates one per default.

item.title: Connection to Server Refused
item.description: When you see similar error as below: 1user@example:~$ kubectl get nodes 2The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port? Check for the "$KUBECONFIG" if set and "kubectl config view" output. Chances are, both are empty like below: 1user@example:~$ echo $KUBECONFIG 1user@example:~$ kubectl config view 2apiVersion: v1 3clusters: null 4contexts: null 5current-context: "" 6kind: Config 7preferences: {} 8users: null In this example, we're using the DOKS or DigitalOcean Managed Kubernetes.
